The remaining eons of formation, destruction, and emptiness are all equal in length to the eon of abiding, and each consists of twenty intermediate eons.

In the eon of destruction, the last intermediate eon is the destruction of the external environment, and the preceding nineteen are the gradual abandonment of sentient beings.
These eons of formation, abiding, destruction, and emptiness, each consisting of twenty intermediate eons, add up to eighty. These eighty make up the measure of a great eon.

First, the treasure of the wheel; second, the treasure of the elephant; third, the treasure of the horse; fourth, the treasure of the jewel; fifth, the treasure of the woman; sixth, the treasure of the steward; seventh, the treasure of the military commander.

The five treasures such as the elephant are included in the category of sentient beings. How can sentient beings born from the karma of others be sentient beings belonging to others? How can sentient beings not belonging to others arise from the karma of others?
However, due to previously creating karma mutually dependent on each other, if one of them is born according to one's own karma, the others also arise simultaneously according to their own karma.
The wheel-turning kings mentioned in this way are not only distinguished from other kings by possessing the seven treasures. They are also distinguished by the thirty-two major marks of a great man.
If this is so, how is a wheel-turning king different from a Buddha?
The major marks of a Buddha are clearly and perfectly manifest, while the marks of a king are not, and therefore there is a difference.
Do the people at the beginning of a kalpa have a king or not?
A verse says:
At the beginning of a kalpa, they are like the gods of the form realm. Later, they gradually increase their craving for flavors.
Because of falling, storing, and thieves arising, in order to prevent them, they hire guards and cultivate fields.
The treatise says:
At the beginning of a kalpa, people are all like those in the form realm. Therefore a sutra says:

At the beginning of a kalpa, people are born from the mind, complete in all faculties, without any deficiency, with perfect appearance and a radiant body, able to freely travel through the air, subsisting on joy and delight, long-lived, and abiding for a long time.
There gradually appears a kind of earth essence, sweet in taste and fragrant.

At that time, there was a person who was naturally fond of flavors. Smelling the fragrance, he gave rise to desire and took a taste, then ate it. Other people followed suit, competing to take and eat it.
At that time, it was called the first acceptance of solid food.
Because of the need for solid food, the body gradually becomes heavy and solid, and light disappears. Darkness then appears, and the sun, moon, and stars appear.
Because of gradually indulging in flavors, the earth's essence disappears, and from this, earth-skin cakes appear.
Competing to eat them, the earth-skin cakes disappear, and then forest vines appear.
Competing to eat them, the forest vines disappear, and unplanted fragrant rice appears. Everyone gathers it to eat.
Because this food is coarse, waste remains in the body, and in order to remove it, two paths appear. From this, the male and female organs appear.

Because of the difference in the two organs, the physical appearance also becomes different. Due to the power of past habits, they then look at each other. Because of this, improper thoughts arise, and the demon of lust and desire confuses the mind and body. Losing one's mind, one goes mad and engages in non-celibate conduct.
The demon of lust in the human realm first appears at this time.

At that time, people took fragrant rice as they wished, without storing it. Later, someone was naturally lazy and took fragrant rice for future use, and other people followed suit and gradually stored more.

Because of this, a sense of ownership arose towards the rice, and each indulged in greed, collecting much without satiation. Therefore, where it was harvested, it no longer grew again. They then divided the fields to prevent exhaustion.
Towards their own field portions, a sense of stinginess and protection arose, and towards others' field portions, there was a desire to encroach and steal. The fault of robbery began at this time.

In order to prevent it, they gathered together to discuss and select a virtuous person from the assembly to be employed with one-sixth of their harvest for protection, and he was appointed as the lord of the fields. Because of this, the name Ká¹£atriya arose.

The great assembly revered and honored him, and his grace extended to all lands, so he was also named MahÄsammata, the Great Authorized King. After him, all kings had this king as their first ancestor.
At that time, some people were disgusted with living at home and enjoyed being in quiet places, diligently cultivating precepts and practices. Because of this, they came to be called Brahmins.
Later, there was a king who greedily hoarded wealth and was unable to distribute it evenly to the people of the country. Therefore, many poor people engaged in thievery.
The king, in order to stop this, enacted light and heavy punishments. The act of killing began at this time.
At that time, there were people who, fearing punishment, concealed their crimes and spoke with different thoughts. Lying speech first arose at this time.
In the period of the decline of the eon, there are three minor calamities.
What are their characteristics?
The verse says:
The karmic paths increase and lifespan decreases until the thirteen calamities appear.
Swords, sickness, and hunger appear in sequence, ending after seven days, one month, and one year, respectively.
The treatise says:

From when sentient beings begin to tell lies, the evil karmic paths increase more and more. Therefore, the lifespan of the people of this continent gradually decreases, until the three minor calamities appear when it reaches ten years.
Therefore, all calamities and afflictions have two dharmas as their basis:
First, indulging in delicious food; second, being naturally lazy.
These three minor calamities occur at the end of the intermediate eon.
The three calamities are: first, warfare; second, pestilence; third, famine.

It is said that at the end of the intermediate eon, when people live to be ten years old, people become defiled by attachment to wrong and greedy desires, and their minds are obscured by unequal love. They are entangled by wrong teachings and their hatred increases. As soon as they see each other, they give rise to intense thoughts of harming each other.
It is like hunters seeing wild birds and animals. Whatever they pick up becomes a sharp knife. They indulge in their ferocity and craziness, and harm each other.

Also, at the end of the intermediate eon, when people live to be ten years old, because they possess the above faults, non-humans spew poison and pestilence spreads. Those who encounter it die immediately and it is difficult to save and treat.

Also, at the end of the intermediate kalpa when the human lifespan is ten years, people are also endowed with the above faults, so the gods and dragons are angry and do not send sweet rain. Because of this, the world suffers from famine for a long time, and many die because there is no support.
Therefore it is said that due to famine, there is gathering, white bones, and counting of tally sticks.
It is called with gathering for two reasons:
First, at that time people, due to extreme hunger and weakness, gathered and died.
Second, at that time people, for the benefit of later people, stopped their own food and put it in a small box, intending it as seed.
Therefore, during the famine, it is called with gathering.
It is called with white bones for two reasons:
First, at that time people, due to the dryness of their bodies, died and their white bones appeared soon after.
Second, at that time people, oppressed by famine, gathered white bones, boiled them for juice, and drank it.

There is also the saying about counting grains, which is also due to two causes: first, due to insufficient grain, they count grains to eat them, meaning that in a household, from the eldest to the youngest, they get a little coarse food on the day when the tally reaches them.

Second, it means using the tally to pick out the husks from the old granary, obtaining a few grains of grain, boiling them with a lot of water, dividing them and drinking them together to sustain the remaining life.

However, there is a scripture that teaches the method of treating them, which states: If one is able to observe the precept of not killing for one day and one night, in future lives one will definitely not encounter the calamity of warfare.
If one is able to arouse sincere and pure thoughts and offer a harÄ«takÄ« to the assembly of monks, in the future world one will definitely not encounter the calamity of epidemics.
If one is able to arouse sincere and pure thoughts and offer a lump of food to the assembly of monks, in the future world one will definitely not encounter the calamity of famine.
For how long do these three calamities last?
The calamity of weapons lasts only seven days, the calamity of pestilence lasts seven times seven days, and the calamity of famine lasts seven times seven years. After this, it ends.

As the lifespan of humans gradually increases, there are calamities similar to these in the eastern and western continents. That is, when anger increases, the body becomes weak, and hunger and thirst increase frequently. There are none at all in the northern continent.
It was previously said that the calamity of fire burns the world. The other calamities are also like this, as should be understood accordingly.
What are the other calamities?
They will now be fully explained.
Verse:
The three calamities of fire, water, and wind have the third concentration as their peak.
In order, the inner calamities are equal to the four concentrations, because they are unshakable.
However, their receptacle is not permanent, because it is born and perishes together with the sentient beings.
After seven fires, one water; after seven waters, fire, then wind.
The treatise says:
These three great calamities afflict the sentient beings, causing them to abandon the lower realms and gather in the heavens above.

The first, the calamity of fire, arises from the appearance of seven suns. The second, the calamity of water, arises from a deluge. The third, the calamity of wind, arises from the mutual collision of winds.
The power of these three calamities destroys the world receptacle, and not even a trace remains.
A class of non-Buddhists holds that the ultimate atom is permanent. They say that at that time, the remaining ultimate atoms are still there.
Why do they hold that there are still remaining ultimate atoms?
They say, â€œIn order that later gross things may arise, they must have seeds.â€
We have already said that the wind produced by the karma of sentient beings can serve as seeds.
Or, the wind at the summit of the calamity can serve as a condition and attract the wind that is the seed.
Also, a scripture of the Dharmaguptakas says,
â€œThe wind blows seeds from other places to this place.â€
Even though this is so, we do not admit that when sprouts, etc., are born, they are directly produced by seeds, etc., as their causes.
If this is so, then from what are sprouts, etc., born?
They are born from their own parts.
In this way, the self-same part again produces self-same part, and so on, until the most subtle part is produced from the ultimate atom.
What power do seeds, etc. have in the production of sprouts, etc.?
Apart from attracting and gathering the ultimate atoms of sprouts, etc., seeds, etc. have no power to produce sprouts, etc.
Why is it definitely asserted in this way?
Production from different categories is definitely unreasonable.
What principle is violated?
It would violate the principle of definiteness.
Because the power is definite, there is no fault of indefiniteness.
Like sound, cooked change, etc., are definitely produced from different categories.
Virtuous dharmas are different, but real dharmas are not like this.
It is directly seen that real dharmas are only produced from the same category, like vines producing branches and threads producing cloth, etc.
This is not reasonable. What is unreasonable?
Because it cites what is not established as the proof.
What is not established that is cited here?
Because it is not accepted that vines, branches, threads, and cloth are different.
When the threads are woven together, the arrangement is different and it is called a cloth. It is like an ant trail, etc.
How do we know this?
Because we have never obtained cloth in a single thread, we only obtain thread.
What obstructs us from obtaining cloth?
If there is no complete cloth in a single thread, then there should be a part of cloth on a single thread, but no cloth.
We should admit that the complete cloth is only a collection of parts, and there is no other cloth with parts called cloth.
Moreover, how do we know that the part of cloth is different from the thread?
If we say that cloth must depend on the combination of many supports, then we should also obtain cloth when only many warp threads are combined.
Or we should admit that there is no principle of obtaining cloth at all, because the middle and other edges do not contact the sense organs.

If we say that they can all contact the sense organs in sequence, then the eyes and body should only obtain the parts, and we should not say that they obtain the cloth with parts, because we cognize the parts in sequence and give rise to the cognition of the whole, like a whirling firebrand.
This is because if the clothâ€™s color, etc., were different from the yarn, the color, etc., of the cloth could not be perceived.

If the color, etc., of the cloth were in the yarn, then it would be necessary to admit that a real thing can arise from a different kind of cause, because the color, etc., of each yarn is not of many different kinds.
Or, if the color, etc., of the cloth were in the yarn, then one would not see the cloth in the part of the cloth that has no different color, etc., because that would manifest the cloth.
Or, one would see a different color, etc., in that part, because the cloth would necessarily have a different color, etc.
They admit that the substance of the part is only one, but it has many different colors, kinds, and functions. This is truly a great wonder!

Also, in the light of a single fire, the light is different in the distance and nearness, and there is a difference in the burning and illumination. The differences in the tactile and visible objects would not be possible.

Although the individual atoms are beyond the range of the senses, they can be perceived by the senses when they are combined, just as the effect that they are supposed to produce, or just as the eye, etc., produce consciousness when combined.
Also, when a person with blurred vision looks at scattered hair, if many strands are close together he can see them, but if they are far apart he cannot see them.
The principle is the same for atoms in relation to the sense organs.
Also, atoms are given the name of color, etc.,

and when color, etc., is destroyed, atoms are also destroyed. Atoms are real, while color, etc., is a quality, and it is not reasonable that different substances be necessarily destroyed at the same time.
It is definitely not the case that these two substances are different.
When one examines carefully, there is no earth, etc., apart from color, etc., and therefore they are not different substances.
Also, in their system, earth, etc., are admitted as objects of the eyes and body. How can they be different from color and touch?

Also, when wool, cotton, safflower, etc., are burned, the awareness of them is no longer present. Therefore, the awareness of wool, etc., arises in dependence on distinctions in color, etc., because when they are cooked and transformed, their shape, size, etc., are the same.
It is like the recognition of a pot or basin in a row of ants. If one does not observe their shape, one cannot recognize them.
Who would accept the crazy words of a fool?
Therefore, we should stop the extensive disputes with them.
Where is the summit of these three calamities?
The second meditative absorption is the summit of the calamity of fire, because below it is burned by fire.
The third meditative absorption is the summit of the calamity of water, because below it is soaked and rotted by water.
The fourth meditative absorption is the summit of the calamity of wind, because below it is scattered by wind.
That which is above any calamity is called the summit of that calamity.
Why are the lower three meditative absorptions subject to the calamities of fire, water, and wind?
In the first two and third meditative absorptions, internal calamities are equal to those externally.
That is, in the first meditative absorption, initial and sustained thought are the internal calamity, because they burn and torment the mind, and are equal to the external calamity of fire.

In the second meditative absorption, the feeling of joy is the internal calamity, because it is associated with serenity and moistens the body like water. Because gross and heavy elements in the body are all eliminated by it, the scriptures say that the faculty of suffering is eliminated in the second meditative absorption.
In the third meditative absorption, inhalation and exhalation are the internal calamity, because they are also wind, and are equal to the external calamity of wind.
If one enters this samÄdhi, there is an internal calamity like this. When one is born in this samÄdhi, one encounters the external calamity that destroys it.
Why is it not established that earth is also a calamity?
Because the vessel world is precisely earth. Fire, etc., can oppose earth, but it cannot be said that earth still opposes earth.
What is the external calamity of the fourth samÄdhi?
It has no external calamity because it is free from internal calamity.
For this reason, the Buddha said that it is called immovable, because it is not reached by the three calamities of the internal and external worlds.
Some say:
Because there are Pure Abodes in that realm, it is not destroyed by the calamities.
Because they cannot be born in the formless heavens, nor should they go to other places again.
If so, the vessel of that realm should be permanent.
It is not so, because it arises and perishes together with the sentient beings.
That heavenly realm has no general topography, but like the stars, each one dwells separately.
When sentient beings are born or die there, the heavenly palaces where they live are born and perish accordingly. Therefore the physical cosmos is also impermanent.
